When looking at the inelastic demand task, the researchers observed that ELA exposed female rats were willing to put in significantly more work to receive the remifentanil than the control rats. Their demand was not sensitive to the costs.

To test this, the researchers allowed the rats to press a lever to receive remifentanil, a fast acting opioid. Every time the lever was pressed, the dose administered would get smaller, requiring the rats to increase efforts (cost) to receive desired dose.
Total heroin self-administration and remifentanil demand did not differ between ELA and control groups. However, the ELA group RESISTED extinction (an indicator of compulsive drug seeking).
